questions.text:
Match the following substances with their Respiratory quotient
1. Carbohydrates A. 0.8
2. Fats B. 1
3. Proteins C. 0.85
4. Mixed diet D. 0.7
questions.solution:
The correct match is

1. Carbohydrates B. 1
2. Fats D. 0.7
3. Proteins A. 0.8
4. Mixed diet C. 0.85

Respiratory quotient (RQ) is defined as the ratio of the volume of CO2 produced in L/g to the oxygen consumed in L/g.

The respiratory quotient for various substances:

Substance RQ
Carbohydrate 1
Protein 0.8
Fat  0.7
Alcohol 0.66 
Mixed diet 0.82-0.85

In diabetes, the rate of utilization of carbohydrates reduces in relation to fats, hence RQ falls (approximately 0.7). The RQ is lowest when ketosis is very active.

Note: For all metabolic fuels, the energy produced is the same (20 kJ/L of oxygen).

questions.text: What is the location of the complexes shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows the electron transport chain (ETC) which is located on the inner mitochondrial membrane. 

The electron transport chain (ETC) is a specialized set of electron carriers that can accept electrons. Energy-rich molecules like glucose are oxidized to produce water and carbon dioxide. The intermediate substrates in these reactions can pass on electrons to certain coenzymes like nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2). The reduced forms can then donate electrons to the ETC by which they lose most of their free energy which is used to move H+ through the inner mitochondrial membrane. The H+ gradient thus produced results in the production of ATP. ATP synthesis together with electron transport is known as oxidative phosphorylation. 

Option B - Outer mitochondrial membrane has acyl-CoA synthetase and glycerol phosphate acyltransferase.

Option C - Mitochondrial matrix has citric acid cycle enzymes, β-oxidation enzymes, and pyruvate dehydrogenase.

Option D - Intermembrane space has adenylyl kinase and creatine kinase.

 The reactions in oxidative phosphorylation and the arrangement of complexes that form the ETC are shown below.

questions.text: A father has noticed that whenever his daughter drinks fruit juice, she has multiple episodes of vomiting. He reports to you that his daughter is allergic to fruit juice. After a thorough workup, she was diagnosed to have aldolase B deficiency. Which of the following substrate is accumulated in the blood?
questions.solution:
The substrate accumulated in the blood in aldolase B deficiency is fructose-1-phosphate. 

Aldolase B is also known as fructose-1-phosphate aldolase. It is involved in the breakdown of fructose-1-phosphate into glyceraldehyde and DHAP. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate and leads to hereditary fructose intolerance.

Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to a deficiency of the enzyme aldolase B. It is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism. This occurs when sucrose (containing fructose) is introduced into the diet of infants, usually around 6 months of age.

Defective aldolase B causes the accumulation of fructose-1-phosphate. This will inhibit glycogen phosphorylase and cause accumulation of glycogen in the liver and associated hypoglycemia. Patients will present with vomiting, loss of appetite, and failure to thrive. Hepatomegaly and jaundice may occur. If liver damage progresses, death will occur. 

Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test +).

Treatment is by the complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.

questions.text: An investigator was studying the effects of various poisons on the enzymes of the glycolytic pathway. He plotted the graph for the enzyme catalyzing the conversion of phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate after adding alanine, which is a non-competitive inhibitor. Which of the following graphs shows the effect caused by alanine?

choices.text: The type of plot will depend on the relative concentration of alanine and enzyme.

questions.solution:
Graph C represents non-competitive inhibition. The inhibition of pyruvate kinase by alanine is an example of non-competitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Lineweaver-Burk plot is also known as the double reciprocal plot.

Competitive inhibition (graph A) - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Uncompetitive inhibition (graph B) - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased. Inhibition of placental alkaline phosphatase (Regan isoenzyme) by phenylalanine is an example of uncompetitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: In a sample of DNA if adenine is 23%, what will be the amount of guanine?
questions.solution:
In a sample of DNA, if adenine is 23%, guanine will be 27%.

This is based on Chargaff’s rule which states that the number of purines is equal to the number of pyrimidines.

Purines include adenine and guanine. Pyrimidines include thymine and cytosine. The two strands of DNA are complementary to each other. So, the adenine of one strand will pair with thymine of the opposite strand, while guanine will pair with cytosine.

  • Step 1:

No of adenine = No of thymine

So adenine + thymine = 46%

Guanine + cytosine = 54%

  • Step 2:

No of guanine = No of cytosine

So, amount of guanine = 54/2 = 27%

questions.text: The absorption spectrum given in the image below belongs to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The absorption spectrum given in the image below shows increased absorption at 400nm. Porphyrins absorb UV light at 400nm.

Conjugated double bonds in the porphyrin rings absorb light at the UV spectrum. The maximum absorbance of porphyrins is around 400 nm. This peak is known as Soret band.

The conjugated double bonds in the pyrrole rings and linking methylene groups of porphyrins (absent in the porphyrinogens) are responsible for their characteristic absorption and fluorescence spectra.

questions.text: In the lac operon model, a high level of transcription takes place only when____

choices.text: Both Glucose and Lactose are present
Glucose is present and Lactose is absent
Both Glucose and Lactose are absent
Glucose is absent and Lactose is present

questions.solution:
In the lac operon model, a high level of transcription takes place only when Glucose is absent and lactose is present.

Lac operon is an operon required for the transport and metabolism of lactose in E. coli and some other enteric bacteria.

Lac operon concept

Lac operon model - It is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose. Otherwise, it is switched off. The genetic arrangement of the lac operon helps coordinate the expression of the three main enzymes (5, 6, 7 below) involved in lactose metabolism. The genes include:

  1. lac I - It codes for the repressor protein that prevents transcription of the distal structural genes, lac Z, lac Y, and lac A by interfering with the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter.
  2. CRE (cAMP response element)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  3. Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  4. Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  5. lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  6. lac Y- encodes for lactose permease which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells
  7. lac A- encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase 

The image below shows the genetic arrangement of the lac operon and the process of regulation of lactose metabolism

questions.text: You are a junior researcher studying about the properties of apoproteins.  Which of the following is the basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48?
questions.solution:
The basis for the intestine-specific expression of apolipoprotein B-48 is RNA editing.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing. The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100. In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 48kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

DNA rearrangement, transposition and alternate splicing, do alter gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man suffered from acute chest pain, sweating, lightheadedness, and nausea 1 day back. Laboratory reports revealed raised cardiac troponin. ECG was suggestive of myocardial infarction. Which of the following isoenzymes of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is likely to be raised?
questions.solution:
This patient had an episode of myocardial infarction one day back. Therefore, LDH-1 is likely to be raised in this case of myocardial infarction.

Normally LDH-2 (H3M1) concentration in blood is greater than LDH-1 (H4), but this pattern is reversed in myocardial infarction; this is called the flipped pattern.

LDH enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits. But the subunit may be either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.

Name of Iso-enzyme Subunit makeup of iso-enzyme Tissue from which iso-enzyme has originated
LDH 1 H4 Heart muscle
LDH 2 H3M1 RBC
LDH 3 H2M2 Brain
LDH 4 H1M3 Liver
LDH 5 M4 Small intestine

An increase in total LDH level is seen in hemolytic anemias, hepatocellular damage, muscular dystrophy, carcinomas, leukemias, and any condition which causes necrosis of body cells. Since total LDH is increased in many conditions, the study of iso-enzymes of LDH is of great importance.

questions.solution:
Histidine is a semi-essential amino acid.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on bactericidal activity of immune cells. You find that defects in the metabolism of a particular amino acid lead to dysfunction of nitric oxide production. Identify the involved amino acid.
questions.solution:
The involved amino acid is arginine, which is required for the production of nitric oxide (NO).

NO is an inflammatory mediator synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase.

The given image shows the process of nitric oxide synthesis.

The co-enzymes of NO synthase are :

  • FMN
  • FAD
  • Heme
  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Three isoenzymes of NO synthase:

  • eNOS (endothelial nitric oxide synthase): Found in the endothelium and plays a role in vasodilatation. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • nNOS (neural nitric oxide synthase): Found in the neural tissue and acts as a neurotransmitter. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • iNOS (inducible nitric oxide synthase): TNF-α, IFN-γ and bacterial endotoxins induce hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils to produce this enzyme. It is inducible and calcium independent.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby produces smooth muscle relaxation.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and IFN-γ released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitter in the brain.

Related Pearl: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is referred to a dermatologist for evaluation of vesicles and bullae and increased pigmentation over sun-exposed areas such as the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms, legs and feet, neck, and face. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with variegate porphyria. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The cause of variegate porphyria is the deficiency of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

Variegate porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the PPOX gene, which results in either the deficiency or decreased function of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase. Protoporphyrinogen IX and other intermediates prior to the block accumulate in the urine. Patients are photosensitive.

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase deficiency is seen in acute intermittent porphyria.

Option C: ALA synthase 2 deficiency is seen in X-linked dominant protoporphyria.

Option D: ALA dehydratase deficiency is seen in amino levulinic acid dehydratase porphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding chaperone proteins is not true?

choices.text: They are also known as heat shock proteins
Most of them are associated with the ATPase enzyme
Some bind to hydrophilic parts of proteins to prevent early folding
Chaperonins form a barrel structure for unfolded proteins

questions.solution:
The statement 'some bind to hydrophilic parts of proteins to prevent early folding' - is not true.

Chaperone proteins actually bind to the hydrophobic parts of an unfolded protein to prevent early folding.

Chaperone proteins, also known as heat shock proteins, are special types of proteins that assist in protein folding in a few ways. One way is by binding to the hydrophobic parts of the elongating polypeptide chain and preventing them from folding until the process of protein synthesis is complete (e.g. Hsp 70). Another way is by chaperonin proteins, another type of chaperone protein, which forms a cage/barrel-like structure for unfolded proteins to get sequestered, providing time and suitable conditions to fold properly. (e.g. mitochondrial Hsp 60).

Most chaperone proteins are associated with an ATPase enzyme. This is because ATP hydrolysis is used extensively during the process of protein folding.

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the process of reconversion of alanine formed in the muscles, back to glucose inside the liver. Which of the following is false regarding this cycle?
questions.solution:
The above cycle described is the glucose-alanine cycle or Cahill cycle and it is not active in fed state.

In the fasting state, muscle glycogen undergoes glycolysis. Pyruvate released during this glycolysis is transaminated to produce alanine. Alanine is then exported to the liver, where it undergoes transamination again back to pyruvate by alanine transaminase and enters gluconeogenesis to produce glucose. 

Also, this alanine serves as a transporter of ammonia. After reaching the liver the alanine is converted into pyruvate and glutamate by transaminase. The glutamate enters the urea cycle carrying the ammonia.

Related Pearl: Transport of ammonia in blood (Cahill and Cori cycle)

questions.text:
Match the following glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) with their location.
GAGs Location
1. Hyaluronic acid A. Cornea
2. Keratan sulfate B. Synovial fluid
3. Heparan sulfate C. Mast cell
4. Heparin D. Kidney
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C is correctly matched.

GAGs Location
1. Hyaluronic acid B. Synovial fluid
2. Keratan sulfate A. Cornea
3. Heparan sulfate D. Kidney
4. Heparin C. Mast cell

Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan. Proteoglycans are components of the ground substance of connective tissue. Proteoglycans have a bottle brush appearance.

Hyaluronic acid is the GAG present in synovial fluid. It is also found in skin, bone, cartilage, vitreous humor, and embryonic tissues. It contains repeating units of N Acetyl Glucosamine and Glucuronic acid. It plays a role in morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid along with chondroitin sulfates in cartilage contribute to its compressibility.

Keratan sulfate I and II are the GAGs in the cornea(KSI), cartilage, and loose connective tissue. It is the only GAG that does not contain any uronic acid. The repeating units are galactose and N-acetyl glucosamine in beta linkage.

Heparan Sulfate is found on many extracellular cell surfaces and contains GlcN with fewer N-sulfates than heparin. The predominant uronic acid is d-glucuronic acid Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells where they act as receptors and may participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication. It is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney along with type IV collagen and laminin, where it determines the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration

Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in the liver, lung, and skin and is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI, but its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin

questions.text: The lab values of a patient reveal a total cholesterol level of  300 mg/dl, TG - 150 mg/dl and HDL - 25 mg/dl . What would be the LDL value?
questions.solution:
The LDL value in the above scenario will be 245 mg/dl.

According to Friedewald’s equation

LDL-C = TC - HDL-C - (TG/5) 

Where

  • HDL-C: High-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • LDL-C: Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • TG: Triglycerides
  • TC: Total cholesterol

Substituting the values:

LDL-C = 300 - 25 - (150/5) = 300-55 = 245 mg/dl

Note:

VLDL-C(Very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol) = TG/5

questions.text: After a diet rich in cholesterol, it is seen that the de novo synthesis of cholesterol in the liver decreases. Which of the following enzymes is involved in this?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the enzyme HMG CoA reductase is involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis in the body.

HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.

Long-term regulation of cholesterol synthesis involves regulating the transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase. When there is sufficient cholesterol in the cell, transcription of the gene for HMG CoA reductase is suppressed, and there is decreased synthesis of cholesterol. 

When cholesterol is less, proteases in the Golgi bodies cleave a sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP). The protein which is then formed binds to a sterol regulatory element (SRE) on the DNA. This activates transcription of the HMG CoA reductase gene which increases cholesterol synthesis.

Hormones that influence HMG reductase are:

  • Insulin and thyroxine increase the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Cortisol and glucagon decrease the activity of HMG CoA reductase
  • Statins inhibit the activity of HMG CoA reductase

Other options:

Option A: Acetoacetyl CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction that combines two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense forming acetoacetyl-CoA. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway along with a molecule of acetyl-CoA.

Option B: HMG CoA lyase is involved in ketone body synthesis which converts HMG coA to acetoacetate. 

Option C: HMG CoA synthase catalyzes the reaction where the third molecule of acetyl CoA condenses with acetoacetyl CoA forming beta-hydroxy beta-methyl glutaryl CoA (HMG CoA).

questions.text: A woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency room with severe nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.  She has a fruity odor of breath and is hyperglycemic.  Urine Rothera's test is positive. Which of the following tissues cannot utilize the non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with a positive Rothera's test is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The non-carbohydrate metabolic byproduct increased here is ketone bodies and the liver cannot utilize ketone bodies.

Type I diabetes mellitus is a low insulin state. There is an increased conversion of fatty acids to acetyl-CoA which in turn leads to increased ketone body production. The presence of ketosis can be established by the detection of ketone bodies in urine by Rothera's test.

The ketone bodies synthesized in the liver mitochondria are transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues, where they are utilized by the following steps:

  • β-hydroxybutyrate is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  • Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetate CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  • Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

Ketone bodies are utilized by extrahepatic tissue like the cardiac muscle and renal cortex (prefer the ketone bodies to glucose as fuel). Tissues like skeletal muscle and the brain can also utilize the ketone bodies as alternate sources of energy if glucose is not available.

RBCs cannot utilize ketone bodies as they lack mitochondria. The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies as it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Rothera's test:

  • Saturate 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate.
  • Add 3 drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside
  • Add 2 mL of liquor ammonia along the sides of the test tube.

Development of a purple ring at the junction of the two liquids (shown in the image below) indicates the presence of acetone or acetoacetic acid in urine. It is not answered by beta hydroxy butyrate. 

Related Pearl: Ketone body utilisation

1. 3-Hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase

2. CoA Transferase

3. Thiolase

questions.text: A male patient presented with headache and blurry vision. Fundoscopy showed bilateral papilledema. MRI of the brain was normal and showed no space-occupying lesions. On further questioning, he admits to taking high-dose multivitamin supplements. Which vitamin excess is likely to cause the above scenario?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of increased intracranial pressure in the absence of space-occupying lesions points towards the diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri. Vitamin A excess is the likely cause.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins. The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: All of the following antioxidants primarily function by reducing the rate of chain initiation, except _______.
questions.solution:
Superoxide dismutase acts in the aqueous phase to trap superoxide free radicals and hence is a chain-breaking antioxidant.

Urate, and vitamin E act in the lipid phase to trap free radicals and are also considered chain-breaking antioxidants. 

Antioxidants fall into two classes:

  • Preventive antioxidants reduce the rate of chain initiation of lipid peroxidation.
  • Chain-breaking antioxidants interfere with the chain propagation phase of lipid peroxidation.

Preventive antioxidants include:

  • Catalase 
  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • Selenium - It is an essential component of glutathione peroxidase and regulates its activity
  • Chelators of metal ions such as ethylenediaminetetraacetate (EDTA) and diethylenetriaminepentaacetate (DTPA).

questions.text: Cardiac edema and neuropathy are seen to be present in a patient with suspected nutritional deficiency.  Which of the following biochemical assays would you advise?
questions.solution:
Cardiac edema and neuropathy are associated with a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Measurement of erythrocyte transketolase provides an index of vitamin B1 nutritional status. 

Thiamine diphosphate (Vit B1) is the cofactor of transketolase which is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway, pyruvate dehydrogenase which is involved in carbohydrate metabolism, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase which is involved in the citric acid cycle, and branched-chain keto acid dehydrogenase which is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

Wet beriberi (cardiac) is associated with tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. It is commonly seen in the refugee camps where people consume polished rice-based monotonous diets. Diagnosis of thiamine deficiency can be established by erythrocyte transketolase activity assessment.

Dry beriberi is associated with neurological deficits such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability. Complications include lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his parents with complaints of diarrhea and dermatitis. The child had neutral aminoaciduria and a positive Obermeyer test result. Which of the following is the precursor of the vitamin that is deficient in the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pellagra secondary to Hartnup disease. The vitamin deficiency in this condition is niacin. The precursor of niacin is tryptophan.

Niacin/vitamin B3 is a constituent of NAD and NADP. Its deficiency occurs in a maize-based diet (maize is deficient in tryptophan), carcinoid syndrome (all the tryptophan is converted to serotonin), and Hartnup disease (defective absorption of tryptophan from intestine and kidney).

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra (3Ds):

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Dermatitis (Casal necklace)
  3. Dementia

The image below shows a Casal necklace—a ring-like rash seen around the neck caused by the deficiency of niacin.

Diagnosis of niacin deficiency secondary to Hartnup disease is based on neutral aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected by the Obermeyer test.

Nicotinic acid inhibits the flux of free fatty acids from adipose tissue; so the acetyl CoA pool is reduced; and hence serum cholesterol is lowered. In high doses, niacin is useful to reduce Lp(a) levels.

Niacin toxicity - Nicotinic acid when given orally or parenterally produces a transient vasodilatation of the cutaneous vessels and histamine release. The reaction is accompanied by itching, burning, and tingling. Intake of nicotinic acid in excess of 50 mg/day may lead to liver damage.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male baby presents with a history of fever, irritability, and vomiting. On examination, there is moderate hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum transaminases and elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which enzyme is deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and laboratory findings are diagnostic of tyrosinemia type I and the enzyme deficient is fumarylacetoacetate hydroxylase (FAH).

Tyrosinemia type I or Hepatorenal tyrosinemia is caused by FAH deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease, caused by a defective FAH gene. This results in the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone which are metabolites of tyrosine degradation. The tissues most affected are hepatic, renal, and nervous tissues. The manifestations of these can be seen in the form of an acute hepatic crisis, such as in this case. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of elevated levels of succinylacetone in urine or blood. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC) which reduces the formation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone by inhibiting the degradation of tyrosine. However, this increases the plasma levels of tyrosine. A diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine is also prescribed to patients.

Other options:

Option B: Tyrosine aminotransferase is deficient in tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). It is also an autosomal recessive disease that results in hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. The laboratory finding here is marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid. The treatment here also involves a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C: 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase deficiency causes type III tyrosinemia (neonatal tyrosinemia). Patients might rarely have a mental disability. The liver function is generally normal. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to deficiency of 4-hydroxy-phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase.

Option D: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria. It manifests as progressive intellectual disability. The diagnosis is made by measurement of plasma phenylalanine levels or by detecting phenyl ketones in the urine. A diet low in phenylalanine is the mainstay of treatment. 

The steps and enzymes of tyrosine metabolism are shown below.

questions.text: Identify the type of isomerism shown by the 2 molecules represented in the below image.
questions.solution:
In the above image, D-glucose and D-mannose differ in the position of –OH group in the second carbon atom. Hence, they are epimers.

Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.

Examples for epimers of glucose:

  • Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
  • Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ.  You suspect a disorder due to a deficiency of an enzyme tyrosinase. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism.

The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase again acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. Mutations in the tyrosinase gene lead to a complete inability to produce melanin.

Albinism is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. This manifests as white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-gray in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

Given below is an image of a young child with albinism showing white hair, skin, and pale iris:

Other options:

Option B: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency leads to phenylketonuria. This defect results in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop hyperactivity, agitation, low IQ, and hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency), Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body sweat, and urine.

Option C: The metabolic defect in alkaptonuria is a defective homogentisate oxidase. Patients typically will have dark urine or urine that turns dark on standing, ochronosis(bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue), arthritis, the pigment in the sclera, and ear cartilage.

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous type) is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability.

questions.text: A teenage girl comes to your clinic complaining of easy bruising. She gives a history of prolonged intake of antibiotics to treat her acne. Which among the following vitamin deficiencies might have led to her present condition?
questions.solution:
History of easy bruising after prolonged use of antibiotics is suggestive of menaquinone/vitamin K deficiency. Prolonged use of antibiotics leads to vitamin K deficiency. This is due to the loss of normal bowel flora that synthesizes menaquinones (vitamin K2). Menaquinones type of vitamin K is produced by gut bacteria.

Vitamin K is required for the functioning are the blood-clotting factors II, VII, IX, X, protein C, and protein S. Vitamin K deficiency causes easy bruising, bleeding, elevated prothrombin time, and hemorrhagic disease in newborns.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin. The following are the vitamers of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) is a synthetic compound that is metabolized to phylloquinone.

questions.text: A 30-year old woman is on chronic therapy with the anti-TB drug Isoniazid. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies is likely to develop in this individual?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid, a drug used to treat tuberculosis, can induce a vitamin B6 deficiency.

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli. Important side effects of isoniazid include peripheral neuritis, hepatitis, anemia, rashes, and arthralgia.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity, by adding pyridoxal phosphate in vitro. Direct measurement of the plasma concentrations of the vitamin (pyridoxal phosphate) can also be done.

Therefore, 10 mg/day of pyridoxine is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods are used for the detection of RNA?
  1. PCR
  2. Real-time PCR
  3. RT-PCR
  4. Northern blotting
  5. Western blotting
questions.solution:
The methods that can be used for the detection of RNA are northern blotting and RT-PCR (option D - 3, 4).

PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is a technique used to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It can be used to synthesize millions of copies of the selected DNA sequence in a few hours, enabling the detection of even trace amounts of DNA in a sample. Therefore, PCR is used for:

  • Detecting mutant DNA 
  • DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis- Detection of DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene
  • Detection of latent viral infections
  • Carrier detection of cystic fibrosis

Real-time PCR is used for quantitation of the number of viruses present in a sample e.g. viral load in HIV or HBV. So, the treatment modalities can be planned and the response to treatment can be assessed.

RT-PCR or reverse transcriptase PCR is used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric department with characteristic hair as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following genetic mutation will be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image showing an irritable child with kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination is suggestive of Menke's disease. It is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene on chromosome X.

Menkes disease is a rare X-linked recessive progressive multisystemic disease of copper metabolism. In this condition, dietary copper is absorbed from the GI tract but it cannot be transported to blood due to the absence of an intracellular copper binding ATPase (mutation in ATP7A gene). Copper deficiency results in the defective function of the lysyl oxidase enzyme and thus leading to reduced cross-linkage of collagen.

Note :

  • ATP7A: Menkes disease - X-linked                 
  • ATP7B: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive (Chromosome 13) (Option D)

Other options-

Option (A) and (B) are not associated with disorders of copper absorption.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids will have the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Histidine has the maximum buffering capacity at physiological pH.

Histidine has a pKa value of 6.5-7.4 (due to the imidazole group), which is close to the physiological pH of the blood and is maintained in the range of 7.35 -7.45.

The maximum buffering capacity of an amino acid is when the pH=pKa. Therefore, at physiological pH, the buffering action in the blood is caused by histidine.

questions.text: A patient presents with cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. These are manifestations of which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis are manifestations of vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes

  • Succinate dehydrogenase
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
  • Xanthine oxidase
  • Acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

questions.text: An infant was brought to OPD with complaints of copious nasal discharge. On examination, there was a clouding of the cornea and hepatomegaly. The developmental assessment showed significant delay. An x-ray of the chest was taken and is given below. Which of the following enzyme is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of corneal clouding with hepatomegaly with developmental delay and the X-ray showing oar-shaped ribs is suggestive of Hurler's syndrome and the enzyme deficient in this condition is α-L-Iduronidase.

Hurler's syndrome is a severe type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) - I. It is caused due to deficiency of α-L-iduronidase. This enzyme is required for the breakdown of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The deficiency of the enzyme leads to the accumulation of these mucopolysaccharides. 

Affected children usually present between 6-24 months of age. Clinical features include hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, enlarged head circumference, joint stiffness, short stature, skeletal dysplasia, recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and persistent copious nasal discharge. Children with Hurler's syndrome have impaired language function because of intellectual disability which occurs due to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and combined conductive and sensorineural hearing loss.

Skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis multiplex includes oar-shaped ribs(widening of anterior ribs), ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged diaphyses of the long bones, macrocephaly, and enlarged J-shaped sella.

The image below shows coarse facial features and the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and phalanges.

Other options:  

Option A: Hunter syndrome is a type II MPS. It occurs due to the deficiency of iduronate 2-sulfatase. It shares the same features of type I MPS like coarse facial features, short stature, and dysostosis multiplex. However, there is no corneal clouding. It is the only MPS which X-linked recessive inheritance. So if a female baby is affected in the family, it is less likely to be Hunter syndrome. 

Option B: Sanfilippo syndrome A or MPS type III-A occurs due to the deficiency of heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

Option C: Sanfilippo syndrome B or MPS type III-B occurs due to the deficiency of α-N-Acetylglucosaminidase enzyme, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate. The affected children usually have delayed milestones and motor dysfunction.

questions.text:
Match the enzyme with the disease caused by its deficiency.
           Enzyme          Disease
 1. Glucose-6-phosphatase a. Cori's disease
 2. Muscle phosphofructokinase b. McArdle's disease 
 3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase c. von Gierke disease
 4. Glycogen debranching enzyme d. Tarui's disease
questions.solution:
Enzyme          Disease
1. Glucose-6-phosphatase

c. von Gierke disease
2. Muscle phosphofructokinase

d. Tarui's 
3. Muscle glycogen phosphorylase

b. McArdle disease 
4. Glycogen debranching enzyme

a. Cori's disease

Von Gierke disease (Type Ia glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase enzyme in the liver, kidney, and intestinal mucosa. Patients present commonly by 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia (leading to seizures), lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. Affected children often have a doll-like face with fat cheeks, relatively thin extremities, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen due to massive hepatomegaly. The kidneys are also enlarged, whereas the spleen and heart are not involved. Laboratory findings include hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria.

McArdle disease (Type V glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency. It appears in late childhood or the second decade of life. The typical manifestations are muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon.

Glycogen debranching enzyme deficiency is seen in Cori's disease (type III glycogen storage disorder). Failure to debranch glycogen into glucose subunits results in the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer-branch chains which resemble limit dextrin. These children present with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was accompanied by his father to the OPD with dry, scaly dermatitis. On evaluation, he had a deficiency of essential fatty acids. Deficiency of which of the following would have likely caused this child's presentation?
questions.solution:
The deficiency of the essential fatty acid, linoleic acid, is likely to have caused this child's presentation of dry and scaly dermatitis.

Essential fatty acid (EFA) refers to polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) required for biological processes but is not synthesized by the body.

The two essential fatty acids in humans are as follows:

  • Linoleic acid (Omega 6): It is the precursor of arachidonic acid
  • α-Linolenic acid (Omega 3): It is the precursor of eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid.

Clinical Significance of PUFA and EFA

  1. PUFAs are used for esterification and excretion of cholesterol.
  2. Deficiency of EFA causes acanthocytosis, hyperkeratosis, acrodermatitis, and hypercholesterolemia.
  3. EFA deficiency is connected with acrodermatitis enteropathica, hepatorenal syndrome, and CNS manifestations.
  4. Elevated PUFA levels are seen in Zellweger’s syndrome.
  5. DHA levels in the blood are low in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.
  6. Trans fatty acids will compete with EFAs and may increase the EFA deficiency and decrease the fluidity of membranes.

Other options:

Options A & B: Oleic and palmitoleic acids are non-essential fatty acids. They can be synthesized in the body naturally. 

Option D: Arachidonic acid is non-essential fatty acid as it can be synthesized from linoleic acid.

questions.text: A scientist is trying to develop a drug for a genetic condition. He seeks a drug that could cause epigenetic alteration in the DNA and could prevent the disease or seemingly improve the condition. All the following would include epigenetic modifications, except _______.

choices.text: Altering the gene sequence of DNA
DNA methylation at CpG islands in promoter regions

questions.solution:
Epigenetic changes are heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. They alter gene expression without mutation.

The term “epigenetics” means “above genetics.” It refers to the regulatory mechanisms that do not change the underlying regulated DNA sequence, but rather change the expression patterns, or function, of the DNA. Epigenetic mechanisms play key roles in the establishment, maintenance, and reversibility of transcriptional states. It can cause both gene activation and inactivation.

Epigenetic modifications include

  1. DNA methylation- It is the covalent addition and subtraction of a methyl group to DNA. Methylation is typically done in cytosine preceding a guanine (CpG) dinucleotides. CpG islands are mainly present in the promoter region.
  2. Histone modifications such as acetylation, deacetylation, methylation, phosphorylation, etc. Acetylation of histone activates transcription, while deacetylation represses transcription.
  3. miRNA- micro RNA or miRNA are approximately 22 nucleotides long. They do not code. They bind to mRNA and inhibit its translation.

Clinical significance of epigenetic mechanisms:

  • Epigenetic modifications, such as histone acetylation and DNA methylation, are reversible, which makes them amenable for application in therapeutic intervention.
  • Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors and DNA methylation inhibitors are being tested in the treatment of cancer. These agents inhibit transcriptional silencing and thus reverse the chromatin condensation in cancer cells.
  • These modifications include heritable changes such as X-inactivation and genomic imprinting, but they can also result from dynamic post-translational protein modifications in response to environmental influences such as diet, age, and drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following region of mRNA offers protection from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease activity?
questions.solution:
The poly(A) tail protects the 3′ end of mRNA from 3′ → 5′ exonuclease attack and facilitates translation.

Eukaryotic messenger RNA usually undergoes post-transcriptional modification and polyadenylation is an important part of this post-transcriptional modification. They help to stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation. After the mRNA enters the cytosol, the poly-A tail is gradually shortened.  Eukaryotic mRNAs have poly-A tails at 3' end and 7-methylguanosine caps at 5' end.

Other options:

Option A: The attachment of mRNA to the ribosome is mediated through the guanyl cap at the 5' end. It also prevents the attack of 5′→ 3′ exonucleases

Option B: TATA box is the site of pre-initiation complex formation, which is the first step in transcription initiation.

Option D: Shine-Dalgarno sequence initiates translation in prokaryotes.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a deficiency of which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
A patient diagnosed with primary hyperoxaluria is most likely to have a glycine deficiency.

Primary hyperoxalurias are a group of inborn errors of metabolism characterized by oxalate overproduction, with an autosomal recessive inheritance. There are 3 types of primary hyperoxalurias, of which primary hyperoxaluria type 1 (PH1) is the most common form.

The defect in PH1 is the deficiency of the alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase in liver peroxisomes. This causes failure to catabolize glyoxylate to glycine. Glyoxylate is instead converted to oxalate, with consequent calcium oxalate stone formation and crystal deposition in various organs like the kidney. 

Age at onset of symptoms ranges from infancy to the sixth decade, with the median age being 4–6 years. Presenting symptoms include hematuria, dysuria, pain, urinary tract infection, or stone passage. In severe, early-onset disease, there is nephrocalcinosis with or without nephrolithiasis and failure to thrive related to renal failure.

A urinalysis shows elevated urinary oxalate and elevated urinary glycolic acid. There is also an elevated level of plasma oxalate. Renal ultrasound may show multiple bilateral radiopaque calculi. 

The FDA recently approved lumasiran, an RNA interference therapeutic agent targeting glycolate oxidase, as the first treatment option for PH1, a rare genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions ensues when there is a deficiency of the rate-limiting enzyme in the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) is the rate-limiting enzyme of the urea cycle. The deficiency of this enzyme results in Hyperammonemia type 1.

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I utilize CO2, ammonia, and 2ATPs to form carbamoyl phosphate.

 

Other options:

  • Deficiency of ornithine Transcarbamoylase results in hyperammonemia type 2.
  • Deficiency of ornithine Permease results in hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria (HHH) syndrome.
  • Deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase results in type 1 tyrosinemia.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. Mental retardation is seen in infants.

questions.text: Choose the option in which the enzyme and its function are incorrectly matched.

choices.text: DNA polymerase - involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization
Helicase - prevents premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA
Topoisomerase - relieves torsional strain caused by unwinding of DNA
DNA ligase - sealing nicks in DNA strands

questions.solution:
Helicase is not involved in the prevention of premature reannealing of double-stranded DNA (dsDNA); this is the function of single-strand binding proteins (SSBs)

Helicases belong to a class of proteins involved in DNA replication. They are involved in ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options:

Option A- DNA polymerases - Involved in deoxynucleotide polymerization

Option B- Topoisomerases - Relieve torsional strain resulting from unwinding

Option D- DNA ligase - Seals nicks in the DNA strand during replication

questions.text: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an allosteric regulator. Which of the following is true about fructose-2,6-bisphosphate?

choices.text: Formed by phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-1
Fall in fructose-2,6-bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis

questions.solution:
Option C is the correct statement. A fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels favors gluconeogenesis.

This is a bifunctional enzyme and has the activity of both phosphofructokinase-II (PFK II) and fructose 2,6 bisphosphatase. 

  • PFK-II converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-2,6-bisphosphate. 
  • Fructose-2,6-bisphosphatase converts fructose-2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate. 

Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate allosterically activates PFK-I, which is involved in converting fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate in glycolysis. In the well-fed state, fructose-2,6-bisphosphate acts as an intracellular signal that indicates that glucose is abundant, thereby causing an increase in the rate of glycolysis. 

In contrast, during fasting, there is the phosphorylation of this tandem enzyme by glucagon. This phosphorylation causes the inactivation of the PFK-II part and activation of the fructose-2,6-bis-phosphatase component. This results in a fall in fructose 2,6 bisphosphate levels, which favors gluconeogenesis.  

Other options:

Option A: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is formed by the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate by phosphofructokinase-2.

Option B: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is the most potent positive allosteric activator of phosphofructokinase-1.

Option D: Fructose-2,6-bisphosphate is an inhibitor of fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase.

questions.text: Which of the following is a substrate for gluconeogenesis?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, propionyl CoA acts as a substrate for gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis is the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. Though it is an energy-consuming process, it is necessary to maintain blood glucose levels. It is needed as a fuel for erythrocytes and brain.

Other substrates for gluconeogenesis include:

  • Oxaloacetate is a direct precursor of phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Pyruvate, an α-keto acid that can be converted to glucose.
  • Glucogenic amino acids like alanine, cysteine, glycine, etc, by the actions of transaminases, yield pyruvate.  
  • Lactate, obtained from anaerobic glycolysis, is released from skeletal muscles and RBCs into the blood. It is taken up by the liver via Cori cycle to be oxidized to pyruvate, to eventually synthesize glucose.
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue is converted to dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the liver, which itself is an intermediate of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

Acetyl CoA and compounds that give rise to acetyl CoA alone like acetoacetate, lysine, and leucine cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose. This is because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. These compounds give rise to ketone bodies instead.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient is very conscious about her body image. She started a diet having only 20 g per day of carbohydrate or less, but with unlimited consumption of fats and proteins. Her previous diet usually had an average of 100-120 g/day of carbohydrate. What will be the effect of this new diet plan?

choices.text: Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight loss
Inhibits gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain
Increases gluconeogenesis and promotes weight gain

questions.solution:
The given patient has adopted a very low carbohydrate diet as a new diet plan and this promotes weight loss and gluconeogenesis.

A very low carbohydrate diet, that is less than or equal to 20 grams per day of carbohydrates with unlimited consumption of fat and protein, has been promoted as an effective regime for weight loss. Since a lower amount of carbohydrates are consumed and there is a continual demand for glucose, gluconeogenesis from amino acids occurs. The associated high ATP cost is then met by the oxidation of fatty acids.

A ketogenic diet is similar. It consists of high fats, moderate proteins, and very low carbohydrates. In a 2000 kcal per day ketogenic diet, carbohydrates should be 20-50 grams per day.

When there is low carbohydrate availability, gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis come into action. When glucose availability drops further and, the endogenous gluconeogenesis cannot keep up with the needs of the body, ketogenesis begins. Ketone bodies replace glucose as a primary source of energy.

During ketogenesis, due to low blood glucose feedback, insulin secretion is also low, which reduces fat and glucose storage. There is also an increased breakdown of fats that result in fatty acids, which get metabolized to ketone bodies. This metabolic state is referred to as 'nutritional ketosis.' The nutritional ketosis state is considered safe, as ketone bodies are produced in small concentrations without changes in blood pH.

questions.text: Biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycans involves attachment to core protein, chain elongation, and chain termination. The synthesis of these core proteins occurs in ________
questions.solution:
Biosynthesis of Glycosaminoglycans involves attachment to core Protein, chain Elongation, and chain Termination. The synthesis of these core proteins occurs in the Endoplasmic reticulum.

Synthesis of GAG:

  • Synthesis of the core proteins: Endoplasmic reticulum
  • Biosynthesis of glycosaminoglycan chains and their subsequent modifications: Golgi apparatus

Glycosaminoglycans or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. They may be attached to a protein molecule to form a proteoglycan. Proteoglycans are components of the ground substance of connective tissue. Proteoglycans have a bottle brush appearance.

The biochemically important GAGs are as follows:

  • Hyaluronic acid
  • Chondroitin sulfate
  • Keratan sulfate
  • Heparin
  • Heparan sulfate
  • Dermatan sulfate

questions.text: The enzyme involved in the process of oxidative deamination shown in the below reaction is allosterically activated by ______
questions.solution:
Glutamate dehydrogenase is involved in the process of oxidative deamination reaction. It is allosterically activated by ADP.

Transfer of amino nitrogen to α-ketoglutarate forms glutamate. Hepatic glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH), which can use either NAD+ or NADP+, releases this nitrogen as ammonia.

Conversion of α-amino nitrogen to ammonia by the action of glutamate aminotransferase and GDH is often termed “transdeamination.” 

Liver GDH activity is allosterically inhibited by ATP, GTP, and NADH, and is activated by ADP.

questions.text: Type of odor seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency  is:
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odour is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies leads to defects in utilisation of biotin. In neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures and even coma may occur. Affected infants should be treated with biotin.
